content:
er 5, 2011
												It's DOOM. Play this if you like old-school games, gaming history and/or well-designed shooters & somehow haven't tried it yet. What else is there to say about it?Alright, I'll give it a shot. In 1993, ID Software more or less revolutionized the first-person shooter genre (again) with a game that was not only blazingly fast and good-looking for the time, but played and aged so well it inspired a fanbase that persists to this day.There have been tens of thousands of custom maps and modifications for Doom and its immediate sequel over the years that take the game in every conceivable direction, and while the 'Doomer' fandom isn't exactly the monstrously huge construction you'd expect to find camping on tumblr*, there's no sign of Doom being truly abandoned any time soon.You might think, yeah, it was good in its day, but it looks so crude and simple today. Why would anyone still play it? Well, apart from the huge realm of custom content, Doom's gameplay is simply very, very well-tuned. It's a little comparable to bullet hell or chess, in that there's more focus on dodging enemy attacks than there is on tanking them.Doom's monster AI is simple yet open-ended enough to make for a wide variety of tactical situations, and the player's movement & weaponry aren't any less finely crafted. The one criticism that I can think of is that the gatling gun (which is also incorrectly referred to as a 'chaingun') more or less replaces your starting pistol.Basically, it's easy to get into, but has enough nuance and depth to carry itself even today. For a while after it was released, games in a similar style were explicitly called 'Doom clones'. To the modern observer, Doom managed to drive progress in the genre enough that in hindsight there really wasn't much shame to be had in being a 'clone' of such an excellent game. (Shoving hundreds of WADs from the Internet into a commercially-released CD was another story.[doom.wikia.com])You can't look up or down either, at least not in the game's original form. While there's absolutely something to be said for Doom's purity of form (and compensating autoaim), the ability to look in any direction is kind of a boon for newer games.You probably wouldn't want to play this for the story: you'll literally only find the setup in the game's manual. There's just enough story to justify what's happening in the game, although what's there is good for what it is.Once the technology was in place, Doom also became a catalyst for early online gaming. This game is, in fact, where the term 'deathmatch' came from. There's still[zandronum.com] options[www.zdaemon.org] available to play Doom with or against other people, without the murderous rates people had to pay 20 years ago. Perhaps bare-bones in comparison to today's offerings, but certainly faster in pace and intensity.Steam's included DOSBox port is pretty poor, so I would recommend grabbing a sourceport like Chocolate Doom or ZDoom. Those two are my personal favorites - the former lets you experience the game as it was in the '90s, and the latter lets you easily load all sorts of modern mods and enhancements.Doom's default controls are frankly a relic from the pre-WASD standard days, but fortunately pretty much every sourceport lets you change the controls and even look up & down if you wish. I would recommend at least trying the original controls, though, if you're going to start playing Doom.If you really want to experience classic Doom, you'd do well to pick up its aforementioned sequel at the very least. It adds new enemies and one new weapon, not to mention 32 new levels, and it's been more popular with custom level designers ever since it came out in 1994. That may not sound like much, but then again, if it ain't broke...As of this humble summation of Doom, the game in question has persisted for 23 years. I would seriously bet that it will last 23 more.*Not that I particularly dislike tumblr, of course.

content:
, 2013
												Now this is the one everybody remembers.  If you played a PC game in 1995, you played Doom.  Everyone played Doom.  Companies had to institute rules and ban Doom from being played during business hours, because too many employees were playing deathmatches.  Doom was so popular that Microsoft developed a port of it to work on their new Windows 95, in hopes of getting more people to buy the operating system, this of course after Bill Gates toyed with the idea of buying out ID Software all together.But even with its popularity, there was the mounds of controversy.  Some hated it for its high levels of blood and gore, others for its satanic symbols.  Groups tried to ban it, tried to get it out of the public eye, blamed it for school shootings and random acts of violence.  Many tried to connect it to violent behavior in young adults, citing the violence learned in the game being brought to reality.  But through all of this it stood tall, exactly what it was, simply a game.Doom is one of those classics that everyone needs to experience   You don’t have to play the whole thing, or beat every level under par.  But every gamer, that wants to truly be a gamer, should spend a little time running around the halls of the UAC facility on the Mars moon.

content:
er 30, 2016
												How much I longed to play it again, but this time here, on Steam. The last time I replayed Doom was... wow, I don't even remember. I might have launched it few times in last 10 years but I know for sure that I didn't finished it from begin to end in all this time. So here I am, replaying another classic and legend of PC gaming.Game from 1995 should feel really old, right? Outdated graphics, sounds, controls and more. It's not the case with Doom. Even low resolution (which can be somehow fixed/changed to higher anyway) is not a problem. Graphics still looks great, soundtrack is one of best made in gaming history and controls... playing a FPS game using only keyboard never felt more comfortable than in id Software games. After so many years it's still played by many players - be it original version or with single and multiplayer mods. It's so much fun, game where killing is fun, level designs makes you use your head and SECRETS, who doesn't love secrets? Fighting your way in 4 episodes, which are filled with many missions. Even if you are playing on "normal" difficult level, it's easy to nice that with every next level game is getting harder. And getting 100% on kills, items and secrets on every level is harder that it looks, that is if you are playing without any guides.Some people will probably think that this price tag is kinda funny - paying this much for 21 years old game!? I bought my copy at sale but still, in my opinion, Ultimate DOOM is worth every price. It's legendary game, so if you never played it - do it right now or wait for sale, if you think they are asking too much for old game.

content:
y 24, 2015
												Doom is quite simply the best shooter ever made and it's not just the nostalgia talking. The pure unadulterated ultra-violence is still as raw and visceral as it was when it was released in 1993. In terms of pure enjoyment in the form of fast paced action, this game delivers in spades. It is what every shooter today pretends not to be as they try to disguise themselves under thinly veiled attempts at plot and character development, a no-brainer all out gore fest. It gives us what we want from a shooter with no unnecessary bells and whistles too often used in modern FPS games to cover up the fact that the game play is simply lacking behind the masquerade of fancy graphics and tedious cut-scenes that ultimately get in the way of the fun, I'm looking at you Call of Duty. I love intricate stories and fully developed characters in games, notable examples of these are the Mass Effect and Witcher series, but this is a genre that has never been about that. This is a genre where the only time you should get a break from the action is the loading screen between levels. Moreover, thanks to the dedicated and thriving fan base there are a plethora of mods and custom WAD files that are constantly breathing new life in to this game. 21 years later and there are still multiplayer servers active, that alone is pretty impressive.

content:
20, 2016
Uh oh! The map is being overrun by enemies! Do you:A. Escort a poorly programmed essential A.I. through monotonous level design for a QTE finale?B. Grind your way through ham-fisted and mind-numbing exposition atop consecutive turret sections?C. Hold down the fire button as the rail-shooter pulls you through an abysmal excuse of a narrative?The correct answer? D, baby. D is for Doom.Your mission is simple: rip and tear your way through the hordes of hell with your arsenal of bloody mayhem, experiencing the revolutionary shooter that set the world afire and the tears of outrage and controversy flowing. The godfather of the FPS genre is still in excellent shape, even after more than twenty years since release. Don't let the system requirements put you off, this runs perfectly well on new operating systems with a few tweaks. It's pretty easy to take for granted from a modern perspective what games such as Doom, System Shock and Half-Life had on the gaming industry upon their release; almost single-handedly creating and then revolutionising the FPS genre. The phenomenal response to the shareware release of Doom and it's colossal (and enduring) success is due to absolutely nailing the formula and standard that id had previously set with Wolfenstein.From the exceptional level design, full of secrets and opportunities for your trusty shotgun to earn its keep, to the brilliant soundtrack backed by excellent sound design as yet another imp is blown away, Doom is everything that many shooters have forgotten: Simple, bloody, fast and instantly gratifying chaos. When was the last time you played something that was this much fun?Too outdated for you? Then install Brutal Doom, the Project Brutality add-on or various source ports to bring the blood into a whole new era. Welcome back, marine."Good? Bad? I'm the guy with the gun." Hell awaits.

content:
, 2016
												If you buy this, or any of the other classic DOOM games, you have 2 options to have a decent experience:1: Get the .WAD files and use them with a source port of your choice, however this wont track your stats on steam.2: Put a source port in the game directory and rename the source port exe to 'dosbox.exe' and delete the original dosbox of course. This will let you run a source port and still have Steam track game time and show when you're playing it.Don't even bother using the DOSbox emulation that comes with it, it has performance issues, runs in an awful resolution, has awful sound emulation, and has no mouse look option whatsoever, if you plan on playing it 100% faithful to the original DOS experience, don't use DOSbox, build or buy a 486.Wait, a review for the game? Saying great things about it is basically copypasta at this point, you've heard it before.

content:
er 9, 2016
												For 10 bucks you'd at least expect a proper port that doesn't require extra configuration, editing tons of text lines and downloading of other files over the internet to actually work. Doom is amazing. This port isn't.The newer your operating system, the least chances to not crash on start.If you are new to the Doom series and want to give the first 2 games a shot, use a source port such as GZDoom[gzdoom.drdteam.org] or ZDoom[zdoom.org] instead. There are many ports out there and not only are they easy to install and use, but also come with better option menus that allow for different resolutions, graphical settings, modern controls and vertical mouselook.If you're still rotting for this vanilla feel this steam port is supposed to bring, try out the Chocolate Doom port[www.chocolate-doom.org], which simulates how the game was played back in the 90's.

												So, If you're planning to buy this game. DO IT. But make sure you buy all four games together in the classic pack. It was only 24 bucks in my country so it'll probably even less in yours! If you don't live in Bahamas or The South Africa of course. Doom was made back in 1993 by ID software and it completely changed the game industry with it's terrific theme and beautiful atmosphere but it wasn't only those two what made this game popular. It is also known as the father of all the FPS games we know today (After Wolfenstein 3D made a year before doom by the same devs.) and It is definitely worth getting back to those old times and want to try a fantastic and a challenging game. The level design was perfect. The atmosphere was great that it still managed to scare me at some points of the game. Not even mentioning the soundtrack which is impressive! Compared to Doom II, I found this one better. The only thing that broke the DOOM II is it's complicated and interesting level design. If you don't want to spend hours trying to beat one map. Get this one. You can also download tons of WADs and mods to contiune the fun even after you finish the game. In conclusion, just buy it already. Trust me it'll be worth it...

content:
9, 2014
												As you can tell by my profile picture, I like this game. I play it again every few years. It's really amazing to see how different first person shooters were when id software was the only one's doing it and had nothing to compare to. You don't look up or down, aiming in the vertical plane is done automatically. There is no commanding officer shouting orders through a radio. The story is told in the instruction manual and by a paragraph at the end of each episode. No need to reload weapons. DOOM was made with one goal in mind: shoot everything and anything that moves. Usually when you play a really old game, you think about how good it would be with modern graphics, but with DOOM there is some sort of uniqueness about its graphics, you don't seem to mind. Bottom Line: DOOM is absolute carnage. A must play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2016
												Different light levels, full texture mapped environment, stairs and elevators, all in a 3D world (kind of).What seems completely irrelevant for today standards, was absolutely mind blowing in 1993, and changed the FPS industry forever.Now, let's look at the game from a 21st century perspective. Is it still a good game? Yes, it is. DOOM, the game that set the world afire It may not be the best game ever (some would say I'm wrong) but it's insane that, 23 years after it's release, DOOM is still a really fun game, with a fast paced action that is hard to find nowadays. Enemies are braindead (just like every other game from the 90's) and most of them aren't any threat individually, but when you have 30 of them in your face, things start to get really complicated very quickly, and if you don't have the necessary reaction speed, you're dead. As simple as that.The story isn't anything great, but honestly I wasn't expecting that kind of ending (I won't spoil it ;)Another thing is the community. This game probably has one of the biggest modding communities of all time, having thousands of maps, mods and TCs.Play it. You probably will need a source port, since DOSBox doesn't work very well. There's a lot to choose from.Chocolate Doom if you want the MS-DOS experience.ZDoom if you want the original graphics but with high resoutions. EDIT: With the pain of my soul, I must inform that ZDoom deveploment stopped. I wouldn't rely on it anymore.GZDoom, Zandronum or Doomsday if you want OpenGL Support.Those are just a few, but they're the best ones in my opinion.PS: All of you people worried that new generations don't appreciate these gems, hope isn't lost! I'm 16!

content:
3, 2016
												This is my favorite game of all time. Not my favorite FPS of all time, My absolute favorite. This game was a technical marvel of its time. If you take the SNES verision of this game and put it next to the PC version, you will see that PC blows console out of the water(As usual).  Now that we have all of the tech and bashing out of the way lets get into the actual game! You are an unnamed space marine for the UAC. You are stationed on one of Mar's moons on a base that has been attacked by the horrors of hell. Enough story I want to shoot some demons! As soon as you press new game, choose which episode you want to play, and which difficulty you want to take on hell with, you are immediately dropped into E1M1, The Hanger, with pistol in hand with demon zombies to kill. There is no health regeneration in this game, no M4 carbine with unlimited ammo, no automatic checkpoints, and no hand holding what so ever. As soon as the level starts you are on your own to kill and explore. That is the beauty of this game there is no restriction on where you can go. If you see an area with bad guys outside? You can go there. You see a chain saw and you want it more than anything in the world? Look for a wall to open and go get it and find some meat! The gameplay is the best thing about this game. The primal satisfaction from seeing that enemy go down in a bloody gorey mess from the blast of your shot gun is like no other. The story is there, but it never really matters that much. John Carmack, the lead programmer for the game, has stated this hilarious phrase, "Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important." The music in this game is absolutely phenomenal. At DOOM's gate, the music from E1M1, is ingrained into every person who has played this game. The music is down and dirty metal. It fits the game very well. All in all, I would absolutely recommend this game. For $5 dollars this game is a no brainer. Especially when it's on sale for a little more than a buck. Now that the sales pitch and review of this game is done, I will have to say that the MS DOS port does not look good in today's standards. I do recommend that you pick up a source port so that you can have the game support your native resolution, mouse support, mods, etc. It's not hard to install or set up, it just consits of finding the source port, I recommend Zandronum, copy the WAD from the location you installed and paste it into your source port. That's it!I may be a 16 year old kid, but I see what this game has done to the FPS genre. I love all of the mechanics of this game and will always be coming back to this game for years to come.Thank you so much for bearing with me for this long review,Uncle Teo(P.S. Don't judge my hours played I have played this a lot with a source port that doesn't keep track of my hours)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2015
												IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER: The game is a port from DOS. Some people who have purchased this version of Doom have experienced a problem where the game's colors turn into a chaotic mess. There are, however, mods out there that you can use to fix this problem if you happen to use this version of the game. Now on to the main review.I made a review for this game a while back. However, I don't believe that review did the game justice, so here's a more proper review.First of all, if you're new at Doom and are eager to try it out, you'll find this review useful. Anyone who is familiar with this game already knows what made Doom a work of art, so this review is for anyone who wants to try it.What Makes this Game so Special?The game was made in '93, a time when video games were much different from today. Far different. Long before Doom, it was commonplace to be making games about shooting aliens from a space ship, and quite a few other interesting titles that I won't both going into. What you need to know is that when Doom came out in '93, it had new ideas and innovations for gaming, or more specifically, the shooting genre.Now to make things clear, Doom obviously isn't the first FPS (Wolfenstein, duh). Doom is, however, a game that managed to define the FPS genre as a gritty, in-your-face, gut-spilling type of world where your annihilate your enemies with firepower. It had that hostile atmosphere to it, one that emphasized on survival through violence as you shoot through wave after wave of bloodthirsty, demonic aliens. Fun side note: the game also had multiplayer. Then there was the game's engine, which allowed the developers to create all kinds of amazing levels, many of which also featured puzzle-solving, which we'll get more into later.So yeah, that's what makes this game so special, even to this day.How is the Gameplay?Pretty simple and straightforward, actually. Run around with a gun, shoot things, collect items, and look for a way out of the level to progress to the next. That's basically the concept of every single FPS game after Doom, so it's not rocket science. That doesn't mean that this simple concept is bad, because like any FPS, the fun comes from blasting the living ♥♥♥♥ out of the enemies that dare oppose you. Doom is able to make this concept fun because of the gore and violence (which is able to make the game's atmosphere look hostile), the variety of weapons, the challenge, and the constant supply of enemies for you to destroy. That is the basic formula for any singleplayer FPS game that is fun and enjoyable. You can use a wide variety of weapons from the shotgun, the pistol, the plasma gun, and a whole bunch of other weapons. You will be ambushed by swarms of demonic hordes ready to tear you to shreds, and the only thing that's going to keep you alive is your trigger finger and a gun, rocket launcher, or BFG 9000. You'll be forced to solve puzzles and run around the map in search of keys to unlock doors, always on the constant look out for more ambushes. There will also be a few horror elements in this game, none of which are terrifying, to be honest, but if your threshold isn't too tough, chances are you'll get a good scare from time to time. Just about all of the game's horror elements involve forcing you to go through dark corridors in order to progress through the next level, so you never know what kind of monsters will be attacking you. Other horror elements include ambushes from tight spaces. Is it terrifying? No, because you can fight back and eliminate the threat. Can it be creepy and give you a good scare? Yes, but only if you're the type of person who doesn't play many horror games, or none at all. There's also a good variety of enemies for you to kill.With all of these features combined into the game, it's no wonder that Doom made a hit.What is the Story?The story isn't interesting, but that's not what makes the game amazing. Besides, the story itself, even though it uses the same old cliches you've seen in many movies, is perfectly fitting for Doom. You play as a space Marine, who is basically a badass that isn't scared of anything. You and your squad were sent to the Phobos moonbase near Mars in response to a distress call. However, your entire squad is brutally killed by demonic monsters, and as the only survivor, your only choice is to fight your way out of the mess you got yourself into. It's the perfect story that fits a game where your survival depends on gritty combat.What Else Does this Game Offer?This game has a lot to offer besides the base game. Doom has always had a large, dedicated community that constantly made mods for it, and it still does today. There are tons of mods out there that will interest you. For example, are you looking for a mod that makes the game look a bit neater, contains more gore, and gives your gun iron sights? There's Brutal Doom. Do you want a mod that allows Doom to stay in its more traditional roots, but still adds in some new content? There's tons of them out there (Google is your friend if you want to find out more of these mods). There's tons of other mods that add in their own spin on the game, so you've got yourself a gold mine here. Is There Anything Bad About this Game?First of all, if you were to criticize Doom, chances are its fanbase will get offended and start chasing after you like ravenous wolves. But from my own honest, unbiased opinion, is there anything bad about Doom at all?For me, the answer is no, but that is because I enjoy playing this game, and its mods. The base game itself is very challenging, and if there is one, amazing thing that Doom got right, it was making an FPS (one of the first FPS games, mind you) that actually made you feel like you playing a fun, worthwhile game. There are too many shooters out there these days that end up being mediocre pieces of crap that think shelling out a load of meaningless, wasteful DLCs is the way to go (not that I hate DLC, I just hate it when devs rely on it because they're too lazy to actually add substance to the game, and instead give you a piece of crap where the only thing that matters is cosmetics). Let me elaborate on this. Is Doom linear? yes. Does that mean Doom is bad? No, because Doom's linear gameplay allows you to explore as you progress. Some shooting games are so stale and pale that they treat you like a complete dumb ♥♥♥ by telling you where to go without ever giving you a chance to explore. Can you argue that the game is bad because of its graphics? No, you can't at all. Yes, this game is from the '90s. Yes, it has visible pixels. But if you ask me, Doom's visuals don't look bad at all. I believe the visual style of this game gives you a retro feel (obviously because it's old, duh), but more than that, it shows you how simplicity in a game can be incredibly fun.So as far as the game itself is concerned, Doom isn't bad. I will, however, argue that this port on Steam is bad and unstable. I want to actually be able to paly a game that I can see, not one where the screen gets messed up with a chaotic collection of red, blue and green colors. That is why I ended up using ZDoom so I can play the old game with full classic settings and actually have it in working order.Also, if there is one thing you can complain about Doom, it's the fanbase, one that is filled with a bunch of tryhard hipsters constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing at each other over which mod is better. Then there's the other group of deadbeats out there that feel like they're special because all they play is the unmodded, classic version, and go on a ranting spree against anyone who plays the game with mods. Seriously, whatever happened to playing the game however the hell you wanted to play it without having everyone freaking out like morons? SMH.Conclusion:You like shooters? Wanna try out an epic classic? Buy this game, but be warned of a few possible problems you may run into with the visuals. Mods can fix it tho.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												I may only have five minutes of playtime, but that was the best five minutes of my life.But for real, Doom is an amazing game that's stood the test of time better than any other game out there; the community is still highly active and the mod scene is still going strong after 23 years, people are still speed running the game and Doomworld holds Cacowards every single year to showcase the best mods and wads of the year. You just don't see that kind of activity with many other games from the 90's (except for Quake). I mean, the game outsold Windows '95 and was promoted by Bill Gates! Everyone knows Doom, and I'm glad to say that it's my favorite game of all time.If you want to play Doom, download a modern source port like (G)ZDoom or Zandronum, play through the game vanilla, and then dive into the ocean of mods and wads. There are great mods like Smooth Doom, Reelism, Project MSX, Samsara, Fractal Doom, DemonSteele, and Doom64 EX. If Ultimate Doom, Doom 2, TNT: Evilution, and The Plutonia Experiment didn't have enough maps for you, then you've got great wads and mega-wads like UAC Ultra, Pirate Doom, Scythe 1/2, Alien Vendetta, Speed of Doom, Claustrophobia 1024, Plutonia 2, Community Chest #1-4, the recent Japanese Community Project, and so many more. Oh, and you can't forget nuts.wad!And don't forget to celebrate Doom's birthday on December 10th by playing Doom and shooting the Cyber Demon until it dies. Cheers, Doomguy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2016
												I've been playing this game and its sequel Doom II - Hell On Earth since they came out, so ignore my play time here. Buying this gets you the DOOM.WAD (and DOOM2.WAD for its sequel) which you can then use with a source port, and with a modern machine it's pretty much the only way to play. Choose between enhancements galore with ports like GZDoom, or go with a more vanilla experience with the likes of Chocolate Doom.The first game probably had the best level design of the series, and yes I'm including the latest game of the series in that comparison too, and is worth a play through for that fact alone. None of the dull, boring corridors you're expected to fight in these days. Doom has entire facilities to explore with no correct way to go about it. Spending a bit of extra time exploring will often reward you with secrets.Just don't forget to save often. Being able to manually save your game whenever you want, something that modern games don't seem to bother with these days, gives you much more freedom in your approach to exploration. Scared to jump into an acid pool to see if there's a secret? Save the game then! None of this save-point rubbish that we have to put up with in today's games.If you haven't played Doom you're missing out on not only witnessing an important part of digial history, but playing an awesome game that still stands up today too.

content:
2015
												Probably my favorite FPS of all time (if you can't tell). Just a few things I want to add:1: I think the Playstation version is the best version of Doom. It has IMHO the best soundtrack of the bunch, it's dark ambient music that makes the game feel completely different than the PC versions. Not only that, the entire game is darker, and some areas have dynamic lighting, adding to the mood. If you are interesting in playing a version of Doom that makes you feel a bit more connected to the isolated atmosphere, I highly recommand playing the PSX version. If you don't have a PSX, google Doom PSX TC, a total conversion that allows you to play the PSX version on PC. 2: If you liked my last recommendation, I also highly recommend Doom 64 EX, it has the same mind behind the ambient soundtrack from the PSX version, but with all new monsters and levels exclusive to the N64 version. Again this game is dark, isolated, and gives a completely different feel than the original PC versions.

content:
er 23, 2016
												Hundreds of major media outlets have already described Doom's influence on the greater games industry. Books have been written about it. It's been made into a feature film, had two major reboots, and bears a relatively small but massively dedicated community, consisting of people who have been playing for 23 years. I am one of those people. I feel as if I have done everything there is to be done with Doom, having beaten every episode, played hundreds if not thousands of add-on WAD files, *made* several add-on WADs myself (many gameplay patches and one new level), and become an influential person in the community myself.It should be obvious how much I recommend this game. Buy it and you will never, ever run out of things to do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2015
												IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER: The game is a port from DOS. Some people who have purchased this version of Doom have experienced a problem where the game's colors turn into a chaotic mess. There are, however, mods out there that you can use to fix this problem if you happen to use this version of the game. Now on to the main review.I made a review for this game a while back. However, I don't believe that review did the game justice, so here's a more proper review.First of all, if you're new at Doom and are eager to try it out, you'll find this review useful. Anyone who is familiar with this game already knows what made Doom a work of art, so this review is for anyone who wants to try it.What Makes this Game so Special?The game was made in '93, a time when video games were much different from today. Far different. Long before Doom, it was commonplace to be making games about shooting aliens from a space ship, and quite a few other interesting titles that I won't both going into. What you need to know is that when Doom came out in '93, it had new ideas and innovations for gaming, or more specifically, the shooting genre.Now to make things clear, Doom obviously isn't the first FPS (Wolfenstein, duh). Doom is, however, a game that managed to define the FPS genre as a gritty, in-your-face, gut-spilling type of world where your annihilate your enemies with firepower. It had that hostile atmosphere to it, one that emphasized on survival through violence as you shoot through wave after wave of bloodthirsty, demonic aliens. Fun side note: the game also had multiplayer. Then there was the game's engine, which allowed the developers to create all kinds of amazing levels, many of which also featured puzzle-solving, which we'll get more into later.So yeah, that's what makes this game so special, even to this day.How is the Gameplay?Pretty simple and straightforward, actually. Run around with a gun, shoot things, collect items, and look for a way out of the level to progress to the next. That's basically the concept of every single FPS game after Doom, so it's not rocket science. That doesn't mean that this simple concept is bad, because like any FPS, the fun comes from blasting the living ♥♥♥♥ out of the enemies that dare oppose you. Doom is able to make this concept fun because of the gore and violence (which is able to make the game's atmosphere look hostile), the variety of weapons, the challenge, and the constant supply of enemies for you to destroy. That is the basic formula for any singleplayer FPS game that is fun and enjoyable. You can use a wide variety of weapons from the shotgun, the pistol, the plasma gun, and a whole bunch of other weapons. You will be ambushed by swarms of demonic hordes ready to tear you to shreds, and the only thing that's going to keep you alive is your trigger finger and a gun, rocket launcher, or BFG 9000. You'll be forced to solve puzzles and run around the map in search of keys to unlock doors, always on the constant look out for more ambushes. There will also be a few horror elements in this game, none of which are terrifying, to be honest, but if your threshold isn't too tough, chances are you'll get a good scare from time to time. Just about all of the game's horror elements involve forcing you to go through dark corridors in order to progress through the next level, so you never know what kind of monsters will be attacking you. Other horror elements include ambushes from tight spaces. Is it terrifying? No, because you can fight back and eliminate the threat. Can it be creepy and give you a good scare? Yes, but only if you're the type of person who doesn't play many horror games, or none at all. There's also a good variety of enemies for you to kill.With all of these features combined into the game, it's no wonder that Doom made a hit.What is the Story?The story isn't interesting, but that's not what makes the game amazing. Besides, the story itself, even though it uses the same old cliches you've seen in many movies, is perfectly fitting for Doom. You play as a space Marine, who is basically a badass that isn't scared of anything. You and your squad were sent to the Phobos moonbase near Mars in response to a distress call. However, your entire squad is brutally killed by demonic monsters, and as the only survivor, your only choice is to fight your way out of the mess you got yourself into. It's the perfect story that fits a game where your survival depends on gritty combat.What Else Does this Game Offer?This game has a lot to offer besides the base game. Doom has always had a large, dedicated community that constantly made mods for it, and it still does today. There are tons of mods out there that will interest you. For example, are you looking for a mod that makes the game look a bit neater, contains more gore, and gives your gun iron sights? There's Brutal Doom. Do you want a mod that allows Doom to stay in its more traditional roots, but still adds in some new content? There's tons of them out there (Google is your friend if you want to find out more of these mods). There's tons of other mods that add in their own spin on the game, so you've got yourself a gold mine here. Is There Anything Bad About this Game?First of all, if you were to criticize Doom, chances are its fanbase will get offended and start chasing after you like ravenous wolves. But from my own honest, unbiased opinion, is there anything bad about Doom at all?For me, the answer is no, but that is because I enjoy playing this game, and its mods. The base game itself is very challenging, and if there is one, amazing thing that Doom got right, it was making an FPS (one of the first FPS games, mind you) that actually made you feel like you playing a fun, worthwhile game. There are too many shooters out there these days that end up being mediocre pieces of crap that think shelling out a load of meaningless, wasteful DLCs is the way to go (not that I hate DLC, I just hate it when devs rely on it because they're too lazy to actually add substance to the game, and instead give you a piece of crap where the only thing that matters is cosmetics). Let me elaborate on this. Is Doom linear? yes. Does that mean Doom is bad? No, because Doom's linear gameplay allows you to explore as you progress. Some shooting games are so stale and pale that they treat you like a complete dumb ♥♥♥ by telling you where to go without ever giving you a chance to explore. Can you argue that the game is bad because of its graphics? No, you can't at all. Yes, this game is from the '90s. Yes, it has visible pixels. But if you ask me, Doom's visuals don't look bad at all. I believe the visual style of this game gives you a retro feel (obviously because it's old, duh), but more than that, it shows you how simplicity in a game can be incredibly fun.So as far as the game itself is concerned, Doom isn't bad. I will, however, argue that this port on Steam is bad and unstable. I want to actually be able to paly a game that I can see, not one where the screen gets messed up with a chaotic collection of red, blue and green colors. That is why I ended up using ZDoom so I can play the old game with full classic settings and actually have it in working order.Also, if there is one thing you can complain about Doom, it's the fanbase, one that is filled with a bunch of tryhard hipsters constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing at each other over which mod is better. Then there's the other group of deadbeats out there that feel like they're special because all they play is the unmodded, classic version, and go on a ranting spree against anyone who plays the game with mods. Seriously, whatever happened to playing the game however the hell you wanted to play it without having everyone freaking out like morons? SMH.Conclusion:You like shooters? Wanna try out an epic classic? Buy this game, but be warned of a few possible problems you may run into with the visuals. Mods can fix it tho.

content:
ber 13, 2014
												Welcome to paradise...a land where angels are roaming-oh sorry...wrong speech. Ahem...WELCOME TO HELL! A land where demons came out of a portal and killed everyone in a base on Mars (Cause why not let one single man live?) and one lone space marine survior must grab massive guns and shoot anything that stands before him...and getting to the most beautiful planet...Earth. That is BASICALLY the storyline, in this game, there was barely any storyline. This game was meant for men (and women, but mainly men find the attractiveness in retro gore) who just wanted to shoot things and blow stuff up for no absolute reason and have tons of fun. The demons you fight are actually well-designed and so are the levels. This game was made in 1995 and was an instant blast! This was a game where only one kid's parents would allow him to play, so everybody would attempt to be his friend and look to him as the "cool guy/kid" and they would hang over at his house and play Doom all...night...long...! I still love this game and have already spent twelve hours into it, and will spend more! This is a childhood memory that won't go away for a very...long...time!Summary: Like retro gore and tons of action with a game that doesn't really have a storyline?...You met your guardian angel!WARNING: I recommend this to teenagers, not to younger children, for this game is quite violent despite the 1995 graphics!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 17, 2014
												I love this game. Love it!!!!Doom is the first game I ever got truly addicted to, and still to this day I find myself whipping it up on any format I can get it on.I've had this from the start on Shareware disks of just the first episode, to the full version on PC, Gameboy Advance, N64, iOS, even the RPG version on phone!The game itself is pretty dated now of course, but that doesn't matter. It just doesn't. This game stands up to the test of time, and is just awesome! Gorey before a game could show individually gibbed body parts, and carrying a deep demonic storyline (i say storyline, it has a basic idea of story from A-B but is no feature length movie-esque COD. Nor does it need to be) and is the true Godfather of the FPS.There were a few that came before it to set the standard of the 3D element, but THIS is the one that made the effort! Buy it standalone, or buy it as part of the iD pack and try its predecessors too to see what paved the way to this slice of gaming History. Marvel at pixelated blood spatter as you chainsaw a Pinky Demon between the eyeballs, and then laugh as its body rotates on the spot to face you from every angle you look at it (this was a function that was not developed until Quake, i believe?).Levels are fairly linear - go through a maze of corridors, taking out all foes in your path to collect the keycards to get through the access doors to beat the badassses to destroy the head honcho to save the world. But with loads of guns and loads of ammo and loads of hellish enemies and some proper banging music! Perfect time after time! :DThis game, will ALWAYS be my number one. My first true love. Always.

content:
, 2016
!!Important note!! Doom doesn’t work on my windows 10 laptop it crashes at the start, but it is easily fixable, you can download a launcher called zdoom, which is free and you will be able to easily get the game up and running on it. There is a link below to zdoom.   What I liked about Doom •	The game has an awesome soundtrack.•	There are many secrets throughout the levels to be found.  •	The monsters in the game were pretty cool to fight. •	Awesome levels. My favourite chapter in the game is Inferno•	A great arsenal of weapons. The shotgun and the chainsaw were my favourite weapons to use. The weapons have a real kick to them, makes you feel like a badass as you go around killing enemies.   •	I liked how at the end of the levels it showed you a map telling you, where you have been and where you are going to next.•	You can mod the game. Highly recommend you try brutal doom or Project brutality.• I like it how you can see doomguy's face at the bottom of the screen, seeing how he reacts to being shot at or attacked. What I disliked or was disappointed with •	Chapter four isn’t that good. A very difficult chapter, especially at the start.My conclusion Doom was one of the first video games I ever played, I have fond memories of it. It is a brilliant first person shooter and made even better with brutal doom or project brutality. I highly recommend it.  83/100Zdoom http://zdoom.org/Downloadbrutal doom http://www.moddb.com/mods/brutal-doom

y 9, 2016
Review For Ultimate DoomReview by: SansPros :- Good Gameplay- Old school graphics- lots of modsCons :Review :The Ultimate Doom a.k.a Doom 95. An old school first person shooter from the 90'sIt's a great game with lots of mods for it. You are a space marine by the game "Doomguy", and you have been sent to Phobos to investigate the facility after a secret experiments went wrong, and it's now hell on Phobos. You job is to kill the Cyber Demon and close the portal to hell.The game is quite simple, kill everything and get to the end. There are secrets in each level and can give you some weapons earlier than normal.There is a mod called Brutal Doom that gives new weapons, Aiming, extra realistic gore, remasteded music and more. The mod gives Doom a more brutal experience and a ton more fun to play.I grew up with Doom as i child and have always loved it, so i hope this review helps you if, you some day wants to buy the gamesAdditional Infomation :Developer:  id SoftwarePublisher:  GT InteractiveGenre: FPS, Single playerReleased: 30. apr 1995Follow my Curator page :http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/This review is written for :The Panda's Corner

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2012
												Taking no credit away from its genre predecessor, Wolfenstein 3-D, DOOM was the breakthrough game of 1993, and the more influential of id's first- person shooters. Its arsenal of powerful guns (namely the shotgun and BFG), intense level of gore and perfect balance of adrenaline-soaked action and exploration kept this gamer riveted for years. Initially a shareware product on PC, DOOM also offered the first multiplayer death- matches via LAN. Doom is creepy, atmospheric, with a sense of impending dread that always seems to be just around the next corner or behind that door. There couldn't have been a better name for the game. cod is better lol♥♥♥♥vault 101/10

content:
2, 2016
												What in God's name can I say about this game that hasn't been said over and over again? The gunplay is satisfying, the enemies are all unique, well-designed and challenging without being unfair, the emphasis on movement and agility makes the game feel more frenetic and involved, the level design is top-notch, mazelike but not beginner-unfriendly, the subversive humor is endearing instead of dated, nor is it tastelessly offensive (in a game about demons from Hell, for that matter), THE BIG ♥♥♥♥ING GUN, the environment design is cleverly disturbing and nightmarish, the pixel graphics feel retro in a good way, and the music is like a 16-bit, MS-DOS hair growth formula mixed with an automatic headbanging machine. People don't kid around when this game is placed among the best FPS of all time.

content:
er 28, 2014
												The only reasons for not getting this game are: if you can't stand outdated graphics, if you dislike corridoor FPS, if you demand realism, if you are a specific type of religious person.The only reason why you should get this game: not a single glaring gameplay flaw. (Use Doom Legacy)There are many other reasons, the game is fun and challenging, atmosphere is great, there are some puzzles, world records to beat, but these days gameplay mechanics are so messed up in most games, that the primary reason I keep getting back to Doom is to take a rest from cussing at the game.Although this game has history with some public shooting incidents, sports heavy metal music and you basically play an alternate to Jesus, this is not Postal or Hatred. Romero had originally planned to give the story a much greater importance, but for whatever reason, it did not end up the way it was visioned in The Doom Bible. The final product is a pure shooting gallery and the only objective is to have fun. Finally, how you take it or what you do with it is you problem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												No game has ever changed an industry like DOOM has, nor has a game delivered so much fun.STORYUnfortunately, there's not much to DOOM's plot. All you need to know is that Hell has taken over Mars and it's moons, and you are the last space marine alive on Mars' moon of Phobos. The story hardly progresses and when it does, it only appears through text screens. So, if you're in it for the story, you won't find much here, that's for sure.GAMEPLAYThis is DOOM's main strength, and the main reason you should play the game. DOOM utilises the old-school mechanics of shooters, with health kits and multiple weapons to carry. Your objective in DOOM is to reach the end of each level whilst eliminating monsters, receiving powerups and activating doors and switches. DOOM's gameplay is very simple and can be understood by any player. Enemy choice and enemy positioning is very creative in DOOM, with there being multiple types of enemy, each one being very cleverly designed. Enemies usually appear in groups of 5-30, which can make the game a real challenge. As you'd expect, there's plenty of ways to dispose with these enemies, with weapons ranging from shotguns to chainsaws. All weapons are very useful and well designed. Level design is another outstanding attribute of DOOM. Levels never feel to maze-like or too linear, which is still a perfect match today. Level design is creative and often gives the player a real challenge. Levels are also scattered with secret areas, which reward the player for exploring the level design and wanting to find new things.GRAPHICS/VISUALS/EFFECTSSome will instantly forget about DOOM when they see it's cheap attempts at 3D graphics, but those affect the gameplay in no way whatsoever. However, DOOM's designs are still amazing, everything from box art to level textures are well designed.CONCLUSIONDOOM is a simple run and gun shooter, however it's sheer fun and enjoyment surpasses any flaw and makes it a game for anyone. 10/10, a game that anyone can enjoy and simply understand.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												What else is there to say about Doom? If you haven't played it you should.Doom is the forefather of all modern first-person shooters. Its controls are tight, its level design remains some of the best ever achieved in the industry, its music is legendary, and the shotgun blast remains iconic in the world of shooters.The story is simple, but standard for 1993 games. It begins in the Hangar of the Phobos moon base as the Doomguy fights his way through the forces of hell before arriving on the lost Deimos base. He has to fight his way through even tough challenges here and take down the vile Cyberdemon before descending into Hell itself.The first nine levels of Doom were released as shareware in 1993. It set a benchmark that future games would dream of reaching. It also had one of the first modding scenes in PC gaming.Speaking of mods, one of the downsides to Doom, especially the Steam version, is that the controls and settings haven't aged all that well. Thus, I'd recommend using a launcher. I personally use GZDoom, which you can find HERE[www.osnanet.de].There are other mods that add to the already awesome and timeless gameplay of Doom, specifically the BRUTAL DOOM MOD. This mod adds additional shooting gameplay and a whole lot more blood to the game.If you are a gamer. Specifically a shooter gamer, you absolurely cannot do much better than Doom.Further information about Doom can be found in this video:


YouTube™ Video: Doom: Knee-Deep In the Dead: S1-E5 

			Views: 0		

			Doom was the second major hit from developer ID Software. N'Eligahn talks about its strengths and its legacy on FPS, action and video game history. With footage from the Doom film.		

Game on and take care.

												Talk about a trip to the past of PC gaming. If you're a fan of FPS games and haven't played this ancient relic, give it a try and see how much the genre has evolved, over the ages. The game still holds up quite well today, and I find it much better than a lot of the modern-day FPS games. Though if you want a more enhanced and optimal experience, download one of the many source ports. I recommend ZDoom/GZDoom, but everyone does have their own tastes. Just please don't use DOSBox, unless you're that much of a purist.If you're up for a challenge, go download Brutal Doom. That mod revamps a lot of the game while keeping the Doom feeling intact. Also, flipping the bird at a Cyberdemon is OH SO! satisfying...until he starts blasting twice the BOOM! at you.

content:
ry 17, 2014
												I love this game. Love it!!!!Doom is the first game I ever got truly addicted to, and still to this day I find myself whipping it up on any format I can get it on.I've had this from the start on Shareware disks of just the first episode, to the full version on PC, Gameboy Advance, N64, iOS, even the RPG version on phone!The game itself is pretty dated now of course, but that doesn't matter. It just doesn't. This game stands up to the test of time, and is just awesome! Gorey before a game could show individually gibbed body parts, and carrying a deep demonic storyline (i say storyline, it has a basic idea of story from A-B but is no feature length movie-esque COD. Nor does it need to be) and is the true Godfather of the FPS.There were a few that came before it to set the standard of the 3D element, but THIS is the one that made the effort! Buy it standalone, or buy it as part of the iD pack and try its predecessors too to see what paved the way to this slice of gaming History. Marvel at pixelated blood spatter as you chainsaw a Pinky Demon between the eyeballs, and then laugh as its body rotates on the spot to face you from every angle you look at it (this was a function that was not developed until Quake, i believe?).Levels are fairly linear - go through a maze of corridors, taking out all foes in your path to collect the keycards to get through the access doors to beat the badassses to destroy the head honcho to save the world. But with loads of guns and loads of ammo and loads of hellish enemies and some proper banging music! Perfect time after time! :DThis game, will ALWAYS be my number one. My first true love. Always.

It is a brilliant first person shooter and made even better with brutal doom or project brutality. I highly recommend it.  83/100Zdoom http://zdoom.org/Downloadbrutal doom http://www.moddb.com/mods/brutal-doom

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 3, 2016
												I'll start by saying that I have no nostalgia for this game. My very first experience with Doom was playing the shareware demo for the first time in late 2015, about 20 years after its release, or 2 decades. I was also using the Chocolate Doom Sourceport, which emulates vanilla Doom as closely as possible, so no fancy graphics changes or mouselook or anything of the sort. All I did to the game was rebind the controls to WSAD + Mouse, disable the ENDOOM screen, and had Patch93's Roland SC-55 Soundfont installed. That said, this is easily one of the greatest games I have ever played. Not only does it stand the test of time, but it has aged like fine wine, and I'd imagine it's almost better nowadays than before, where modern shooters are always pushing for better graphics, greater realism, and less of the high speed arcadey action that makes Doom so fun.Movement is fast, fluid, and fun. There is no crouching or jumping, but with the way the game is designed such mechanics would only break the game. The game is balanced around constant movement, whether it's dodging enemy projectiles, picking up ammo/hp, or crossing rivers of toxic waste. You don't stop to reload or take cover, you're always on the move.The weapons are all rather balanced and extremely fun to play with, except maybe the pistol and fists (though, in the defense of the stock melee fists, the berserk powerup makes them incredibly fun and they get replaced by the chainsaw later anyways). The shotgun in particular is extremely versatile and useful throughout the game and is one of the best shotguns in video games, and the BFG 9000 is one of the best video game weapons ever. The lack of reload makes sure that combat stays fast paced while the delay between each fire balances it out and keeps you on the move. The weapons (aside from the aforementioned two weaker ones) all feel like they really pack a punch, capable of killing multiple enemies in one or two shots. The sounds and animations, even though they’re not particularly high quality by today’s standards, still sound and look pleasant and add to the punchy-ness of the weapons (if that makes sense).The enemy design is extremely colorful, creative, memorable, and of course, disturbing. The Cacodemon is a perfect example of this; a red monster with a large spherical body that floats slowly through the air, crowned with horns, and possessing a single green eye over a large mouth which is persistently twisted into an evil grin showing a series of nasty teeth and a bluish interior. And, to top it off, let me quote this wiki description of the Cacodemon’s death animation: “When killed, they let out a whimpering moan and fall to the ground, splitting open like a burst pustule and spewing copious amounts of blue blood and intestines that flow forth to reveal their bared brains, while their sole eye pops out of its socket. Also, some of its horns break.” How do they come up with these monster ideas?These monsters remain fun to play against despite their seemingly basic AI, as often you will have to combat multiple enemies at a time, dodging their projectiles and staying on the move as you whittle down their numbers with blasts from a shotgun. An interesting thing about these monsters’ AI is that they can be tricked into fighting each other. This can usually be accomplished by getting into a position where one monster is in the line of fire of another. The monster, in an attempt to damage you, will hit the one in the line of fire, and the damaged monster will retaliate and attack in revenge without regard. This is a really unique game mechanic, as most games do not give the enemies the ability to hurt each other, much less the ability to retaliate. Monster infighting is a great tactic to use when low on ammo, and it’s just fun to watch two monsters ignore you and fight each other to the death.The level design is complex, sprawling, and loaded with cleverly hidden secrets and alternate paths. Many of the levels here are some of the best out of any video game out there. The replayability value is extremely high with this game because of just how much there is to discover in these levels. You'll still be finding new secrets and even secret exits and secret levels even after replaying this game many, many times. Unlike much of the linear level design of today, this game does not hold your hand and encourages you to go off and explore, and exploration is rewarded with finding goodies such as weapons, ammo, health, armor, or a new path/new exit. The game doesn't point out the secrets directly but rather guides you to them using audio and visual cues. This may be an odd wall texture, or maybe hearing the sound of a door opening far off when you press a switch or button. Sometimes a window may tease a secret behind it, and you'll have to find it using your knowledge of the level. There are even secrets within secrets in many cases (and secrets within secrets within secrets!). Another great thing about the level design is the natural sense of progression it has. You start off in a fully tech-based environment, in the UAC facilities. As the game goes on, the levels become gradually more and more twisted and hellish until everything is either made of stone or meat by the end. You really feel like you've completed a story arc (as simple as it may be).The visuals have aged surprisingly well. 2D sprites for enemies are partially to thank for this, as sprites always look way better than ♥♥♥♥♥♥ early 3D. Another part of why Doom still looks nice today is the textures. They’re low quality, yes, but not in a “blurry vomit of color” kind of way but in a pixely, retro kind of way. I don’t really know how to put it into words. I guess an example might be Deus Ex. Look at screenshots for Deus Ex: the textures are blurry and low res, and the models are low poly and also suffer from having blurry textures over them too. All in all, Deus Ex looks really bad by modern standards (don’t get me wrong though, it’s still a masterpiece game). Doom’s textures and sprites use big pixels that look sharper and cleaner than Deus Ex’s blurry textures. It’s like comparing really good pixel art to a painting behind blurry, smudgy glass. Or something.And the music is just awesome. All of Doom's music was composed by Robert Prince, on a Roland SC-55. I strongly recommend that you find a way to emulate a Roland SC-55’s playback of the soundtrack if you can.  Brandon Blume’s SC-55 recordings for Doom 1 and 2’s soundtracks are compatible with ZDoom and GZDoom, which is probably the easiest and best method of making it work. I didn’t know how to get it to work with Chocolate Doom so I just settled on using Patch93’s SC-55 Soundfont. The actual music is a mix of heavy metal and ambient tracks, drawing inspiration from groups such as Alice in Chains, Metallica, Pantera and Slayer. The tracks add to the atmosphere when they need to, and makes you feel pumped up and ready to kill things when they need to, and overall it’s just a fantastic soundtrack that compliments the game perfectly.Other things of note:The use of toxic barrels in the environment is really cool. Not only can you combat the monsters with your weapons and against each other, but you can use the environment to your advantage against them by shooting barrels and watching them blow up into bits, sometimes creating a chain reaction of barrel explosions.The atmosphere in the game is great, especially in the more hellish levels.The difficulty levels are pretty cleverly named. Much nicer than the typical “Easy, Normal, Hard”The soul sphere’s design is really underrated – a human soul trapped in a blue orb. The first time I came across it I just stared at it for afew minutes, both disturbed and intrigued, and tried to kill it before eventually realizing that it was actually a powerup. Probably my favorite powerup in any game now.TL;DR: 11/10 timeless masterpiece.

content:
ber 13, 2014
												Welcome to paradise...a land where angels are roaming-oh sorry...wrong speech. Ahem...WELCOME TO HELL! A land where demons came out of a portal and killed everyone in a base on Mars (Cause why not let one single man live?) and one lone space marine survior must grab massive guns and shoot anything that stands before him...and getting to the most beautiful planet...Earth. That is BASICALLY the storyline, in this game, there was barely any storyline. This game was meant for men (and women, but mainly men find the attractiveness in retro gore) who just wanted to shoot things and blow stuff up for no absolute reason and have tons of fun. The demons you fight are actually well-designed and so are the levels. This game was made in 1995 and was an instant blast! This was a game where only one kid's parents would allow him to play, so everybody would attempt to be his friend and look to him as the "cool guy/kid" and they would hang over at his house and play Doom all...night...long...! I still love this game and have already spent twelve hours into it, and will spend more! This is a childhood memory that won't go away for a very...long...time!Summary: Like retro gore and tons of action with a game that doesn't really have a storyline?...You met your guardian angel!WARNING: I recommend this to teenagers, not to younger children, for this game is quite violent despite the 1995 graphics!

												What in God's name can I say about this game that hasn't been said over and over again? The gunplay is satisfying, the enemies are all unique, well-designed and challenging without being unfair, the emphasis on movement and agility makes the game feel more frenetic and involved, the level design is top-notch, mazelike but not beginner-unfriendly, the subversive humor is endearing instead of dated, nor is it tastelessly offensive (in a game about demons from Hell, for that matter), THE BIG ♥♥♥♥ING GUN, the environment design is cleverly disturbing and nightmarish, the pixel graphics feel retro in a good way, and the music is like a 16-bit, MS-DOS hair growth formula mixed with an automatic headbanging machine. People don't kid around when this game is placed among the best FPS of all time.

content:
13, 2015
												From soccer moms to Army Rangers, everyone's heard of Doom. Its name may well be synonymous with gaming controversy itself right beside Grand Theft Auto and E.T. It's one of the few 3D games that can say it's old enough to legally drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, and own a handgun in its home country at the time of writing. For a long time, I wanted to play the game that was so important it was deemed a national treasure of the United States. When I finally did, I didn't regret it for an instant.It goes without saying; Doom is old. You can't crouch, you can't jump, you can't look up or down, and it's not even true 3D - 2.5D, as it was called, unable to stack rooms on top of one another. Pixelated monsters and environments straight out of 1993 look like an absolute mess at the ludicrous speeds the player is capable of and autoaim is a fact of life.Despite how undeniably and understandably aged Doom is, it's still a fantastic game. It offers a healthy list of useful weapons with unique roles and a good variety of enemies that provide a fair challenge each. Valuable first-person shooter skills saw their rise to prominence in the bloodstained halls of the UAC labs and remain engaging twelve years later. Pacing that satisfies and yet leaves the player wanting for more contributes to an addicting game that gives the player control of how fast and how loose they want to fight their way through each demon-infested level.Interesting usage of lighting, pleasing level design, detailed sprites and animations - few frames as they had - and a MIDI soundtrack so powerful you'd expect it to take up more than its 800KB in space all drive home Doom's finely aged experience. Even the stock sound effects that Doom relies upon are employed effectively and continue to make their presence heard in video games to this day.It's no wonder that the first-person shooter genre had the title of "Doom clone" when this classic was released. More than two decades after id Software put shooters on the map, Doom is still an absolute treat to play. To those who have yet to see what all the yelling and screaming is about, my recommendation is to take the plunge and start cooking with gas.

												Great fun, this game. I do highly recommend it to anyone who is a PC gamer and doesn't hate fun. That's another thing, this game doesn't have a verticle axis (looking up and down) so don't complain about that. This was 1993, after all. Anyway, a great PC classic and definitely worth a buy, even though it is possible to get it for free.

content:
ry 1
												11/10.I first played this game when I was 6 in 1999 on my dad's copied floppy disc. This game has ingrained the FPS genre inside me from a very young age and I wouldn't have it any other way. The hordes of iconic demons, your extensive arsenal, forboding environments that capture the atmosphere of that spacey hellish theme and the iconic DOOM Guy whom I have idolized for a very long time.- Non-stop action of mowing down demons of various skill- Extremely moddable- Iconic soundtrack by Bobby Prince- This game will literally almost run on anything (even the Macbook's touch bar)- A revolutionary game for it's time that pioneered gaming, popularized the FPS genre to what it is todayThis game is super close to my heart, playing most of the DOOM games up until DOOM 2016 along with replaying more of ID's games, watching the movie (as most hated it I still loved it) and even inking the title on my arm. I cannot fault it, I don't care how biased that is.

content:
, 2011
												The Ultimate Doom is simply an upgraded version of the Original Doom game. I’m going to go ahead and tell you now, there is a good chance of getting eye cancer after play this game, yes it looked that horrendous. It looks great if you’re staring at your screen from afar, but close up these graphics are pixelated. Yeah it’s an old game, but after playing all the modern games you may or may not be able to adapt to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics. If you aren’t able to adapt you may be facing many hours of dizziness and nausea while playing this game. Overall this game was wonderful, the sound effects were very retro but still sounded clear and crisp. The controls were a little wonky and take a little getting used to because you can’t really move your mouse vertically in this game. Believe it or not this game actually has replayability, just mod out the doom mobs and turns them in to Barnies and/or Teletubbies!

												As-is? Don't waste your money. A pathetic DOSBox release with no useful features etc.Follow this guide (took me literally 5 minutes to set it up)


How to run ports\mods through Steam using ZDL 
A Guide for The Ultimate DOOM
By: Bunnings Wharehouse

			A guide to help people run modern Doom ports through Steam using ZDL, this enables Steam Overlay in the modern ports and keeps track of gaming hours.		


And THEN you have a highly enjoyable DOOM experience. Brutal DOOM works, I also tried some other mods like Pirate DOOM and the ZDL loader is a heaven-sent utility.I'm not going to waste space reviewing the game, it's a classic, it's the ♥♥♥♥, it's my favourite game of all time and blah blah blah nostalgia glasses: activate. The first three episodes are pinnacles of 90s FPS perfection, episode four is a bit bland by comparison, and that's all I'm saying.I just wanted to set the record straight that DOOM can be run like clockwork through Steam thanks to this loader.And for those saying "but why should I have to do this if I paid money for it!", I say "Do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want, but if you want a good way of playing DOOM through Steam wiht next to no effort, well, here it is."

content:
9, 2014
												This is officially the first real FPS game. Ultimate Doom is still a fantastic shooter that is still mentioned when talking about non-regenerating health and fast paced running/gunning. Graphics wice Ultimate Doom is a bit of an eye sore (them pixels...) and controls are a bit silly in today's standards (mouse also moves you and you don't have to aim up and down) but the gameplay and atmosphere are still there. There's not much of a story besides marine in Mars, killing everything he sees. Levels get harder fast, demons bigger and the weapons more explosive. For young gamers I only recommend this if you're interested in old hard games or roots of FPS gaming.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2014
												Putting myself into the shoes of a gamer in '93, Doom would have blown me away. Sure, the arcades were feeling Sega's games like Virtua Racing, but somehow managing to get a 3D shooter to run at 25-30 fps purely through DOS, that will run on a home PC in '93 just amazes me. Some very sneaky tricks must have been used to get that '3D' effect working in DOS. With good sound, good level design, and just a very classic feel to it, the overall experience feels like a primitive (but still very enjoyable) form of the games we have today. Back then, it would've really stood out. I say this without nostalgic bias, as I wasn't even alive at the time of release, but I can still see the serious jump Doom had over Wolfenstein 3D, or Pathways Into Darkness by Bungie for the Macintosh. ID Software really had the ball rolling here, with 4 player Deathmatch support, and being a key icon in popularising the fps genre, I'm going to have to hand it to them, it's hard to make a game that will still be enjoyable decades later.For its time, I'd give it a solid 9/10.

												A classic in my mind, albeit one that hasn't aged well. If you must play this game, as I've said in my Doom II review, GET A SOURCE PORT. Not only will the game run a lot smoother, but it allows for custom controls and, of course, mod support. Using the regular DOSBox emulator, the classic Doom games run sluggishly and can even crash.And don't let my small play time fool you. I've actually been playing this and the other classic Doom games a LOT thanks to source ports like ZDoom and Skulltag. They don't track your playtime on Steam, though, unless you can figure out how to get the source port itself to run on Steam.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												It's difficult to know where to begin when reviewing DOOM. For our generation, it's the equivalent of being handed the Bible and asked to give it a score out of ten..... The content isn't so much the important issue here, rather it's the legacy the game left behind.I don't think many people would argue that gaming (especially PC gaming) could be divided into "Before DOOM" and "After DOOM". No, it wasn't the first to do many of the tricks we now take for granted. No, it wasn't the best FPS around. But.... the iPod wasn't the first portable music player and certainly wasn't the best, but it changed the way we listen to music forever. DOOM did the same thing for the FPS, and that's not an exaggeration.You only have to look at the timeline of games development to see that it changed both the industry and people's attitudes. Suddenly, corporate networks were being clogged up with data from employees fragging each other when they should have been working. People at home were able to design their own levels and have others play them. The graphic violence drew criticism from various groups and DOOM was talked about in national media. Every games developer in the world was rushing their own FPS to market to try and cream off some of the publicity DOOM was generating. Some were successful (Duke Nukem 3D), some (Nitemare 3D?) less so.No, it wasn't the first to do any of these things. But at the time it was nothing short of a phenomenon. There was barely a console around which didn't receive some version of DOOM at some point (Even the VIC-20 got one eventually thanks to homebrew).Is it the best game ever? No. But it's very important if you're even slightly interested in games, and you owe it to yourself to at least play it. The industry was never the same again after DOOM. It kick-started the interest in LAN gaming, and made 3D gaming if not the standard, then at least a target to aspire to.iD of course managed to make lightning strike twice when Quake was released, but that's another story...
