content:
9, 2014
												I bought this on Steam just so I could write a review of it, and maybe push id in the right direction with sales. I have actually played this game for hundreds of hours. I probably play it for at least 10-20 hours per year, for every year of my life.Let me make one thing perfectly clear: nostalgia does not factor into this game's enjoyment. Doom still has a very active community, and new mods come out all the time. Thanks to Carmack's programming, Doom made modding a staple of PC gaming, and it hasn't gone away. Getting older has made me see more of Doom's flaws, but I don't really like it any less.Doom is far from perfect. Unlike modern corridor shooters, which almost completely abandon the principles of level design, Doom is made or broken by its level design. There are a few different level designers that worked on Doom, and once you've played enough you can tell each of them just by playing their levels, even if you don't know their names. This means that level design is inconsistent, and therefore you're going to really like some levels and hate others. Most people who played Doom as a kid forgave the bad levels because, well, they were kids. If you're new to Doom, it's best to start at the beginning and play Episode 1 of Doom 1. This is widely regarded as one of the best, if not the best, set of levels for Doom, designed by John Romero. They're coherent, look nice (relatively speaking) and have well-placed secrets. Oddly enough, Doom 64 has one of the best sets of levels and plays like any of the other classic Doom games; google "Doom 64 Absolution" and you can easily find a total conversion mod that basically allows you to play Doom 64 on your computer once you have Doom. Thanks, Midway!Virtually every level can be summed up by "find keys, throw switches, open doors." This sounds bad, but again, it can either be tedious or enjoyable depending on the level's design. I must stress that the player should use their automap (tab key) here. Doom's levels are not afraid of having many twisting paths, and it's quite easy to get lost without it. Helpfully, switches are usually recessed into the wall slightly, which clearly marks them on the automap. If levels truly become tedious, don't be afraid to skip them by typing "IDCLEVXX", where "XX" is a two-digit number following the convention of episode number, then level number. i.e. IDCLEV14 changes to episode 1, level 4. Each episode has 9 levels. I won't lie to you, there are a few quite truly bad levels in Doom, but fortunately id left this cheat code in. Be careful, it starts the level as if you'd started a new game, which means you lose all your weapons except the pistol, and start with 100 health and 0 armor. However, all Doom levels are designed with pistol start in mind, so you should be able to manage with enough skill. Doom should be enjoyed on a level-by-level basis; remember, there is almost nothing in the narrative that ties these levels together. If you really hate a level, you should get used to the idea of just skipping it.The guns... well, everyone knows how the guns work, since they were the basis for almost every shooter arsenal until Unreal came out, notable exception being Rise of the Triad. They're quite well-balanced, actually, with the exception of the pistol, which becomes useless once you get the chaingun. The shotgun and chaingun are good at long range. The super shotgun is probably the best all-around weapon in the game, although it doesn't appear until Doom 2. The rocket launcher and plasma rifle are high-power weapons meant to break out against threatening hordes of monsters, and the BFG is there when nothing else substitutes.  Every one of them has a place in your arsenal, although depending on the levels you're playing, you may be using one a lot more than the other due to ammo distribution. Doom is famously narrative-light. Romero makes a good effort to portray "realistic" military base locations, but the game's somewhat ridiculously deep story penned by Tom Hall was thrown out in short order - trust me, if you'd have read it, you would agree that it is quite over-the-top for a fledgling shooter made in 1993. The inconsistency between levels means that the ultimate choice to abandon any hope of telling a story beyond the intermission text screens was probably for the best. There are a few key events that happen in the plot, but they mostly happen at the end of or between episodes.Overall, I highly recommend Doom for anyone who enjoys shooters but hasn't played Doom before. I also recommend Doom for anyone who is new to shooters, since it was also designed for that audience. If nothing else, it will give them an appreciation for where the genre has come from. This game still holds up very well today, especially with the active modding community. HOWEVER: If you do buy this game, do NOT run it as-is from Steam's library. To run the game on modern systems, it comes packaged with DOSBox, which simulates the MS-DOS environment. The emulation can slow down your computer considerably and ironically make running the game more difficult. You should instead download and install one of the many "source ports," which are redesigns of the actual game engine to make it compatible with modern computers. ZDoom is a good and popular choice. Some "purists" swear by Chocolate Doom, which faithfully recreates the game, merely updating it to allow it to run on modern hardware without such niceties as OpenGL or mouselook.

content:
9, 2014
												I bought this on Steam just so I could write a review of it, and maybe push id in the right direction with sales. I have actually played this game for hundreds of hours. I probably play it for at least 10-20 hours per year, for every year of my life.Let me make one thing perfectly clear: nostalgia does not factor into this game's enjoyment. Doom still has a very active community, and new mods come out all the time. Thanks to Carmack's programming, Doom made modding a staple of PC gaming, and it hasn't gone away. Getting older has made me see more of Doom's flaws, but I don't really like it any less.Doom is far from perfect. Unlike modern corridor shooters, which almost completely abandon the principles of level design, Doom is made or broken by its level design. There are a few different level designers that worked on Doom, and once you've played enough you can tell each of them just by playing their levels, even if you don't know their names. This means that level design is inconsistent, and therefore you're going to really like some levels and hate others. Most people who played Doom as a kid forgave the bad levels because, well, they were kids. If you're new to Doom, it's best to start at the beginning and play Episode 1 of Doom 1. This is widely regarded as one of the best, if not the best, set of levels for Doom, designed by John Romero. They're coherent, look nice (relatively speaking) and have well-placed secrets. Oddly enough, Doom 64 has one of the best sets of levels and plays like any of the other classic Doom games; google "Doom 64 Absolution" and you can easily find a total conversion mod that basically allows you to play Doom 64 on your computer once you have Doom. Thanks, Midway!Virtually every level can be summed up by "find keys, throw switches, open doors." This sounds bad, but again, it can either be tedious or enjoyable depending on the level's design. I must stress that the player should use their automap (tab key) here. Doom's levels are not afraid of having many twisting paths, and it's quite easy to get lost without it. Helpfully, switches are usually recessed into the wall slightly, which clearly marks them on the automap. If levels truly become tedious, don't be afraid to skip them by typing "IDCLEVXX", where "XX" is a two-digit number following the convention of episode number, then level number. i.e. IDCLEV14 changes to episode 1, level 4. Each episode has 9 levels. I won't lie to you, there are a few quite truly bad levels in Doom, but fortunately id left this cheat code in. Be careful, it starts the level as if you'd started a new game, which means you lose all your weapons except the pistol, and start with 100 health and 0 armor. However, all Doom levels are designed with pistol start in mind, so you should be able to manage with enough skill. Doom should be enjoyed on a level-by-level basis; remember, there is almost nothing in the narrative that ties these levels together. If you really hate a level, you should get used to the idea of just skipping it.The guns... well, everyone knows how the guns work, since they were the basis for almost every shooter arsenal until Unreal came out, notable exception being Rise of the Triad. They're quite well-balanced, actually, with the exception of the pistol, which becomes useless once you get the chaingun. The shotgun and chaingun are good at long range. The super shotgun is probably the best all-around weapon in the game, although it doesn't appear until Doom 2. The rocket launcher and plasma rifle are high-power weapons meant to break out against threatening hordes of monsters, and the BFG is there when nothing else substitutes.  Every one of them has a place in your arsenal, although depending on the levels you're playing, you may be using one a lot more than the other due to ammo distribution. Doom is famously narrative-light. Romero makes a good effort to portray "realistic" military base locations, but the game's somewhat ridiculously deep story penned by Tom Hall was thrown out in short order - trust me, if you'd have read it, you would agree that it is quite over-the-top for a fledgling shooter made in 1993. The inconsistency between levels means that the ultimate choice to abandon any hope of telling a story beyond the intermission text screens was probably for the best. There are a few key events that happen in the plot, but they mostly happen at the end of or between episodes.Overall, I highly recommend Doom for anyone who enjoys shooters but hasn't played Doom before. I also recommend Doom for anyone who is new to shooters, since it was also designed for that audience. If nothing else, it will give them an appreciation for where the genre has come from. This game still holds up very well today, especially with the active modding community. HOWEVER: If you do buy this game, do NOT run it as-is from Steam's library. To run the game on modern systems, it comes packaged with DOSBox, which simulates the MS-DOS environment. The emulation can slow down your computer considerably and ironically make running the game more difficult. You should instead download and install one of the many "source ports," which are redesigns of the actual game engine to make it compatible with modern computers. ZDoom is a good and popular choice. Some "purists" swear by Chocolate Doom, which faithfully recreates the game, merely updating it to allow it to run on modern hardware without such niceties as OpenGL or mouselook.

												My UnAPologeticly Bias Review of DOOM 1993 "The Year Gaming Began"It was 1993, What a great year, Bill Clinton in the Whitehouse, The Simpsons & The X-Files on Your TV........And more importantly DOOM on your PCIn 1993 Id Software, The 5 or so Developers of DOOM said FU****CK All this 2D kiddie Garbage and made Game for "Real Gamers" a Game SO EPIC and so Controversial that it has Become the be all and end all In gaming, This Game was so good it inspired many Clones,Mass Shootings, Outrage and Set in stone a template for all future "FIRST PERSON" Games ever to be released , It Stated with with one Simple One simple Philosophy,One Powerful Formula...."Hoards of Evil Enemies bent on World Domination and An Arsenal of Bad A**ss Weapons to Dispatch them With"Here's my review of One of the GREATEST and BEST FIRST PERSON SHOOTER EVER MADETHE AWSOME+The Setting..Its the far Future , Man has invented Teleportation Device and Whoops Dimension Rip , Hoards of DEMONS from hell are pouring out Massacring The Entire Phobos Moon Research Base staff, You are the Lonely Space Marine and you have one Job...WIPE THEM OUT. (play Doom 3 To get the full story) + Weapons are all kids of Awesome, Rip through the DEMON HOARDS with an Array of Awesome Reaslsitc Weapons such as the Shotgun, Pistol and Demon shredding CHAIN GUN and some Sci Fi Weapons like the Plasma rifle and BFG. For some reason there a Chainsaw too, it's not great but Has great potential for Gory kills for the more violent minded player.+The Music is Awsome , It's Like a Rock Concert, and if any one tells your differently tell them to F off. The music is perfect for Chain gunning your way through Hells finest+Modern Controls ,the game uses WASD and mouse to Shoot instead of the weird system they had in 1993.+CARRY 10 GUNS at once none of this 3 gun limit Bullsh*it+The One Retro game u can't be accused of being a hipster for Playing. It's too Awsome for that +U NEE ETO PLAY IT+It's History The bad...more like nit picks - Graphics,  I'm not gonna bash on it too much , there a little dull , it's a mixed bag of grey room, red room, at least it wasent 2D- Finding Key cards can be annoying in Later Levels- you can't Aim up and down, has an Auto Aim of sorts , some Whimps (Pretentious know it all Gamers, your know who u are) out there might complain about thatWait a Minuet your still, reading this long boring review ...what the F are u Doing....get up off your butt, get down to the bank and drop some dollar into that steam account of yours (if u haven't already) and buy DOOM ...RIGHT NOW AND PLAY ITS AWSOME GOODNESSNOW GO and Buy and Enjoy this Gaming piece of History> Oh And Remember Kids"Without Doom , your crappy arsed kiddie Call of Duty Garbage wouldn't exist"DOOM gets the rare Daire OReilly "Best Game Ever" Seal of ApprovalMy Score 666/10UPDATE: Steam Awards December 2016: I nominated this game for the "Test of Time" award because i trully think that this game will live on forever. this game derves it

content:
er 23, 2014
												Oddly enough, I played DOOM II before DOOM in 95, so this was really my second installment in the series, about two years later. Back in 1995 things were simpler — I only had DOOM II, and Hover! so I could just play the obvious choice; come 1996 and (Final) DOOM, and choices were not that easy anymore: there also were Grand Prix 2 and FIFA 97 to be taken care of. Well, even though the choice wasn't easy, it always boiled down to my favourite meat-grinding, first-person gore party. I believe — and this is probably just my heart talking — DOOM II was far better than the original, but even then I knew perfectly that this would be a milestone, this would matter, this would've made history.It's not too late to claim your part in it.

My Review on DOOM needs no Introduction.The Storyline is simple, you're a Space Marine that's transfered to Mars as Security for the Union Aerospace Corporation or UAC While they conduct Teleportation Experments on Mars' 2 Moons; Phobos and Deimos. But when a Teleportation Experment goes astary due to a terrible accident, Phobos Base sends out a distress signal while Deimos Base drops dead & disappears completely. Responding to a frantic distress call from the overrun scientists, the Martian marine unit is quickly sent by ship from Mars to Phobos to investigate, only to find the Phobos Completely overrun by devilspawns from the Gates of Hell & there's one option left: LOCK & LOAD!

content:
9, 2014
												Classic FPS, very accessible and easy to pick up and play for newcommers to the fps genre yet challenging for veterans. There are 5 difficulty levels which dramatically effect the way the game plays. Whether you're looking for some hardcore action with unforgivable enemies or you want to breeze through with a chaingun tearing the demons to pieces, you should play doom.The levels are huge and very easy to get lost in, there are tonnes of secrets to look out for too and loads of ammo/health kits to keep you energized, you can either explore these huge demon filled labyrinths looking for secrets or breeze through the level trying to beat your best time. The art design is great, the computer/monitor sprites are rather detailed for it's time and the enemy designs are very detailed too, particularly the hulking demon enemies you will fight later on in the game. There are also several obtainable weapons and you can carry 1 of each weapon, no stupid 2 weapon limit, once you find a weapon, it's yours... until you die but you can jsut reload a save if you want to keep them, there are some really cool weapons like the minigun and the BFG which differ from your conventional FPS weapon arsenal.The only issue is that you may occasionally find yourself in a dark room, now this is expected in a game like doom, however the flashing lights can be a bit uneasy on the eyes, it would have been better if the flashing was slowed down a touch, i don't reccommend this game to anybody with epilepsy but to everybody else, if you're remotely interested in the roots of the FPS genre or you want to have some kick ♥♥♥ old school FPS action, you need to get this game now!Do note that considering it's age, Doom is missing vital features of more modern FPS such as the ability to aim up and down so it may confuse players who are used to more modern shooters but don't worry as the game will auto aim at enemies in line with your gun no matter what height they are.

content:
ry 2, 2016
The Ultimate DooM		* 10/10The Ultimate DooM on Steam		* 0/10I believe there's not much to say about DooM. Not the first FPS, but I could say it's "The First Bad@$$ FPS Ever. PERIOD". Why the 2 rates? Let's say the 10/10 rate is related to the Game itself (or every Pros I've though of and listed) while the 0/10 is related to the Game As a Steam Release (Everything is listed in the Cons Section). Consider that I grew up with doom, I was 6 years old when the shareware was being widespread all over the world, and still nowadays I own The original DooM, DooM II and The Ultimate Collection DooM 95 (With Ultimate DooM, DooM II And Final DooM). Despite all this I regret to NOT Recommend this RELEASE (Not THE GAME, mind you). On a Side note: all the DooM chapters have been released on Steam like this, so I'm not recommending Any other chapter, specifically DooM II, Final DooM nor even the Master levels for DooM II. My same Review will be posted in all those releases because of the same flaws.+++PROs+++The Following Points are the reason I MUST recommend this Game
 FPS. The genre was defined by THIS game (Yes, yes, there was Wolfenstein before, but the mainstream came with DooM overwhelming popularity). I still feel Adrenaline while sporting around an arsenal of weapons through Maps totally full of monsters and a gameplay that can be summarized as "shoot (or run through) everything that moves and get to the exit". Sounds lame but everything started from here, and simpler things are not boring here. They're Fun. MUSIC. It's a widely known story and it's true. Most of the bad@$$ music you hear in game are nothing but ripoffs from famous Metal or Hard Rock famous songs. How could a game be more Bad@$$ than this? MODS. One of the most Modded game ever. There are even lots of Ports, because DooM originally is a DOS game so it always had few issues with windows' environment (mainly audio related, who remembers autoexec.bat, dos=high umb and other damn DOS lines like them? XD). Lots of famous mods, that can revolutionize the gameplay (like Brutal Doom), or even new maps (See Alien DooM), or totally messed up demented projects (like the Italian And somehow Satyrical/blatantly blasphemous Grezzo 2... I am told it's greatly appreciated around the world... even though most characters are italian or from italian Television, and everything is written/spoken in italian... so... O.o). There are even lots of guides, both in steam and in other sites, with solutions to all of the CONs I've listed.---CONs---The following points are the reason I will NEVER recommend this release on Steam.
 STEAM OVERLAY. This release runs directly with dosbox, so obviously the overlay won't work. THE PORT. Actually this release has no ports... It's the usual game that runs on DosBox... Which is not the best solution because it's just an emulation of a DOS Environment which means that you can easily experience some minor LAGs, both on video and audio. Not to mention the inferior Midi quality. On top of that it has 2 options, the classic input and the DEFAULT "Modern input" with WASD Movement AND Mouse MOVEMENT...Not Mouselook, MOVEMENT. So obviously you can't use the mouse because it goes in conflict with the WASD keys... And you can't use the arrows because ONLY Left and Right are Binded... WHAT THE F**K?!?!?!?!? WHO THE HELL IS THE INCOMPETENT THAT WORKED ON THIS $H17 AND APPROVED IT?!?!?!?!? AND THIS C**P IS THE DEFAULT SETTING!!!! I know there are solutions inside steam's community discussions and guides, but I don't care, releasing a product of the importance as DooM in this state is SIMPLY RIDICULOUS. And you want to know something? Do you remember the Excellent DooM 95 Port where you have a simple window with tidy options and settings? You even have settings to add Mods. Do you know who worked on that project in his Microsoft's days? GABE NEWELL. And here on Steam I have to find this Garbage on DosBox... I could have Downloaded from google in 2 minutes both the WADs AND a DECENT Port IF (i repeat) IF MY ORIGINAL COPIES  Of DooM, DooM II And "Ultimate Doom, DooM II And Final With DooM 95" (Yes I DO OWN ALL OF THEM) were somehow misteriously Burnt out... Steam doesn't consider profitable to ask microsoft a deal to use the best BASIC port for DooM? Fine, Use another one, or make something decent yourself, it's really ridiculous to get such a great game released in such a bad and approximate way... And maybe I'm mistaken, Steam is just a digital distribution platform and the quality of the product released relies on the Developer. It doesn't change anything. The fact that Whoever worked on this release setted the game to play by default with a SELF-CONTRADICTORY INPUT SYSTEM is still RIDICUOUS ... And a reason BIG ENOUGH to AVOID this release LIKE A DISEASE... (Ho-ho-ho, I'm a poet... XD... But seriously, don't waste here your money...)

content:
, 2016
												Honestly, it's a bit clunky. Not being able to look up or down is always annoying. Even worse, moving the mouse forward or back instead moves me forwards or backwards, which is really annoying when I'm trying not to fall. I mean, seriously, what FPS does that, having the mouse move the player? It goes against every gaming instinct I've developed from FPSs.As far as I know, there's no way to change the controls, so I'm stuck with this bass ackwards mouse control.Other than that, there's not much to say. I mean, it's the original DOOM, pretty much. An all-time classic. I would say it's aged relatively well. Graphics can get repetitive, what you have to do isn't always straightforward, and some times the game makes you jump through extra hoops just for some cheap hits (if I remember correctly, in E1M4, you have to get the red keycard, which sets off a flag for more enemies to be released, and you have to get through them to get the blue keycard). But overall, it's fun, it's challenging, and it's DOOM.Hell awaits you... Are you ready for it?

												Do you really need a review? Seriously. This is Doom, the grand daddy of the entire FPS genre. I will say this game has aged remarkably well (especially with mods like Doom Engine, GZdoom and Brutal Doom. The resolution change brings the sprites up quite a bit and there are even mods that replce the sprites with 3D models. In short. This game is a classic and it still kicks ♥♥♥.It will also likely kick your ♥♥♥ mercilessly.

0, 2016
												This game is a legendary game, with many knowing of it and it's legacy. However, this port is pure ♥♥♥♥. Of the four times I ran it, all four times it crashed. The first time it crashed at boot up, the second at the beginning of Map 1 in the firs campaign, the third at the end of the first chapter, and the fourth at the title screen. This is a great game, but this port is a slander to it's greatness, and it's reputation.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 4, 2015
												The game itself being "DOOM" is an excellent fps that defined the genre, but this version is not very good. This DOOM port is  a DOS emulator with the DOOMrom attatched. This means that it is poorly optimized for a modern computer. There is a lack of any controller options, meaning you have to use the origional control scheme which is very tank-like, using the arrow keys to go forward, back, and turining while using the "ctrl" key to fire and holding "alt" to strafe. The mouse support is awful simply acting as the arrow keys. A better DOOM for a modern machine is DOOM 3 bfg edition. This includes all of the DOOM games and all have been updated for a new computer with modern fps controls.
